subject: AW: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods
msgSnippet: hi, but what s about testing setter-methodes, if in there you re doing some value (-range) checks ?! i think then it make sense to test them .. gabi ... Von:
messageBody:
hi,

but what's about testing setter-methodes, if in there you're
doing some value (-range) checks ?! i think then it make
sense to test them ..

gabi



-----Urspr√ºngliche Nachricht-----
Von: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
Gesendet: Donnerstag, 2. Mai 2002 20:41
An: junit@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: RE: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods


Quoting "Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC)" <timothy.j.stevens@...>:

>
> Can't break!!?? You never make typos and return the wrong variable
> in a getter, or set the wrong variable in a setter? If so, you're a
> better
> coder than me :)

I hope this was tongue-in-cheek. I don't think I have *ever* returned the
wrong
variable from a getX() method[1]. In order to make this mistake, I'd have to
be
drunk. As for setting the wrong variable in a setX() method, see my previous

message. I've made that mistake exactly once.

Folks, don't test the getX() and setX() methods; but rather test that the constructor stores the appropriate parameter in the appropriate field. I
know
I'm about 100 times more likely to write a bug there than in the getX() or
setX
() method itself.

J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
President, Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Let's write software that people understand.

[1] Note that I'm ignoring cases where the compiler caught a typo.
